G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, granting the Superior Court original jurisdiction in civil actions where the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Hampden Superior Court, pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the acts complained of occurred in Hampden County, and both parties reside therein.

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care in the ownership, maintenance, and control of property to avoid creating an unreasonable risk of harm to others.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the leading Massachusetts case that abolished the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and adopted a general duty of reasonable care owed by property owners/occupiers to lawful entrants. While the quoted passage is only a concurring opinion criticizing the continued special treatment of trespassers, the core decision of Mounsey supports the broader proposition that, under Massachusetts law, the standard is one of reasonable care in the ownership and control of property to avoid unreasonable risk of harm. The concurrence reinforces a move away from status-based duties, consistent with the claimed principle, but does not itself clearly extend the duty to all persons including trespassers.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors. … The very effort at dry classification and differentiation puts the emphasis at the wrong places. Thus it is awkward to leave the suggestion that the basic reasoning of the court’s opinion may stop short of so called trespassers.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.proposition: Defendant knew or reasonably should have known that the ladder posed a substantial risk of physical injury or property damage under windy conditions.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns negligent storage of firearms and the foreseeability of theft and criminal misuse of a gun, not any knowledge about a ladder or risks posed by windy conditions. Nothing in the case discusses ladders, wind, or property damage of the type described. Therefore, this citation does not support the specific proposition stated about the defendant’s knowledge of ladder risks under windy conditions.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 147\u20134.relevant_excerpt: “In the circumstances of this case, we conclude that a homeowner who permits guns to be stored on her property and allows unsupervised access to that property by a person known by her to have a history of violence and mental instability, has a duty of reasonable care to ensure that the guns are properly secured.”

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: A reasonably prudent person, under similar circumstances, would have secured or relocated the ladder to prevent it from falling.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss ladders, securing ladders, or what a reasonably prudent person would do regarding a ladder to prevent it from falling. The case turns on lack of evidence of causation for a scaffolding collapse and on statutory issues concerning building permits, not on any duty to secure or relocate a ladder. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition about a reasonably prudent person securing or relocating a ladder.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: "The judge found as an undisputed fact that '[n]othing in the materials supplied to the Court explains the reason why the scaffolding collapsed.'... These unsubstantiated conjectures cannot support any claim that some property defect chargeable to the defendant caused (or even contributed) to the collapse of the scaffolding."

O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204\u.proposition: Defendant's failure to act constituted negligence under longstanding Massachusetts precedent imposing liability for foreseeable harms resulting from unsafe property conditions.
O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204\u.support_reasoning: The case rejects liability rather than imposing it. The court holds that, under Massachusetts law, a landowner owes no duty to protect against or warn of open and obvious dangers, and specifically finds that the defendants were not negligent for failing to warn about or prevent diving into the shallow end. This is the opposite of the claimed proposition that longstanding Massachusetts precedent imposed liability here for foreseeable harms from unsafe property conditions.
O'Sullivan v. Shaw, 431 Mass. 201, 204\u.relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that, because the danger of diving into the shallow end of a swimming pool is open and obvious to a person of average intelligence, the defendants had no duty to warn the plaintiff of this danger as a matter of law and, therefore, they could not be found liable for his injuries. The defendants’ motion for summary judgment was correctly allowed.”

Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.proposition: Defendant's failure to act constituted negligence under longstanding Massachusetts precedent imposing liability for foreseeable harms resulting from unsafe property conditions.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.support_reasoning: The case directly addresses a landowner’s duty for unsafe property conditions and emphasizes foreseeability of harm. The SJC holds that a landowner who creates and maintains a dangerous condition on the property, and can foresee that lawful entrants will encounter it despite its obvious danger, has a duty to remedy that condition and may be liable in negligence. That aligns with the proposition that the defendants’ failure to act (to remedy/remove the dangerous trampoline–pool setup) can constitute negligence under Massachusetts precedent focused on foreseeable harms from unsafe property conditions.
Dos Santos v. Coleta, 465 Mass. 148, 153.relevant_excerpt: “An owner or possessor of land owes a common-law duty of reasonable care to all persons lawfully on the premises… This duty includes an obligation to maintain the ‘property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others….’ … [A] landowner… ‘is not relieved from remedying an open and obvious danger where [the landowner] “can and should anticipate that the dangerous condition will cause physical harm to the [lawful visitor] notwithstanding its known or obvious danger.”’ … Here, Jose set up a trampoline immediately adjacent to a two-foot-deep pool… He knew that the setup was dangerous….”}

Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.raw_text: Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d 515, 522 (1st Cir. 1990)
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.proposition: Defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s property damage and financial loss.
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.support_reasoning: The opinion does not hold that the defendant’s negligence was the direct and proximate cause of plaintiffs’ property damage and financial loss. Proximate cause of the accident had already been found by an earlier jury and was not at issue on appeal; instead, the First Circuit addresses only whether harm-to-reputation and resulting economic losses were cognizable and sufficiently proven as proximately caused by Massport’s negligence, ultimately holding the evidence of proximate cause for those losses was insufficient. Thus, the case does not affirm the general proposition stated and in fact rejects proximate causation for the claimed financial losses at issue.
Jorgensen v. Mass. Port Auth., 905 F.2d.relevant_excerpt: “In the liability phase, the jury returned a verdict for the plaintiffs, finding that Massport had been negligent in its maintenance of Logan Airport on January 23, 1982, and that this negligence was a proximate cause of the accident. … The district court overturned the jury's verdict on the ground that the evidence presented in the case ‘was insufficient to support a reasoned finding by the jury that the losses alleged by plaintiffs through harm to reputation were proximately caused by the negligence of Massport.’ … we affirm … on the narrower ground that plaintiffs failed to adduce sufficient evidence that Massport's negligence proximately caused the losses claimed by plaintiffs.”}

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under G.L. c. 231, § 85, Plaintiff’s own exercise of due care is presumed, and no comparative negligence applies as Plaintiff had no ability to prevent the falling ladder.

Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 19.proposition: Defendant’s breach constitutes actionable negligence for foreseeable property damage under Massachusetts common law and the Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 302, 303, as adopted by Massachusetts courts.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 19.support_reasoning: The case discusses a commercial landlord’s common‑law duty to protect lawful occupants from reasonably foreseeable criminal acts, but it ultimately holds there was no duty and no actionable negligence because the assault was not reasonably foreseeable. It does not invoke Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 302 or 303, nor does it find a breach that constitutes actionable negligence for foreseeable property damage. Instead, it limits liability by emphasizing lack of foreseeability and reverses a plaintiff’s verdict, so it does not support the cited proposition.
Whittaker v. Saraceno, 418 Mass. 196, 19.relevant_excerpt: “The defendant testified that he had a duty to provide security. He was correct because, as evolved, the common law imposes on a commercial landowner a duty to take reasonable precautions to protect persons lawfully in common areas of rental property against reasonably foreseeable risks. … The attack on the plaintiff was not reasonably foreseeable. There was no evidence that the landlord knew or reasonably should have known that a physical attack might occur in the building… Here the defendant had no duty to the plaintiff to provide protection against a not reasonably foreseeable act of violence against her.”

Greene v. DiFazio, 148 F. Supp. 3d 116,.raw_text: Greene v. DiFazio, 148 F. Supp. 3d 116, 122 (D. Mass. 2015)
Greene v. DiFazio, 148 F. Supp. 3d 116,.proposition: Defendant’s breach constitutes actionable negligence for foreseeable property damage under Massachusetts common law and the Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 302, 303, as adopted by Massachusetts courts.
Greene v. DiFazio, 148 F. Supp. 3d 116,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a lengthy memorandum on judicial recusal under 28 U.S.C. § 455 in a federal capital case; it does not address negligence, property damage, Massachusetts common law, or Restatement (Second) of Torts §§ 302 or 303. Nothing in the holding or reasoning concerns substantive tort law or actionable negligence. Therefore, this case cannot properly be cited as authority for the proposition about negligence for foreseeable property damage under Massachusetts law and the Restatement.
Greene v. DiFazio, 148 F. Supp. 3d 116,.relevant_excerpt: Rather, the sole basis for the government’s motion is 28 U.S.C. § 455(a), which states that a judge “shall disqualify himself in any proceeding in which his impartiality might reasonably be questioned.” Section 455(a) is based on the premise that in some circumstances “a reasonable person may question impartiality without the presence of any evidence that a judge is subjectively biased.” In re Bulger, 710 F.3d at 46.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award costs, pre-judgment and post-judgment interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;

Massachusetts Rule of Civil Procedure 38.proposition: Plaintiff demands a trial by jury on all issues so triable pursuant to Massachusetts Rule of Civil Procedure 38(b).
